# 總裁報告

2018年是全球金融危機發生十周年，十年間國際政經形勢經歷巨大轉變，當中不乏一幕幕超乎最佳編劇所能想像的場景。我在去年的年報指出，2017年金融市場表現是「喜出望外」，同時提到前景「潛藏隱憂」。回顧2018年，或許可形容為「先喜後悲」。環球多個股票指數在1月創出歷史新高後不久，熾熱的投資情緒旋即遇上中美貿易摩擦的冷鋒，加上英國脫歐談判一直拉鋸、地緣政治惡化、美聯儲四次加息等因素，市場樂觀氣氛急劇逆轉，資產價格在年內大幅下跌。MSCI全球指數從高點至低點曾下跌20.3%，全年累跌約一成，是2008年環球金融危機以來表現最差的一年。恒生指數從高點最多曾下跌26.7%，全年下挫13.6%，錄得七年來最大年度跌幅。

# 聯匯穩健 信心所繫

儘管外圍形勢波動難測，香港金融體系仍然保持穩健，貨幣市場運作暢順無阻。實施三十五年的聯繫匯率制度成功應對了資金流出港元的考驗。自環球金融危機爆發以來，累積約10,000億港元等值的資金流入港元。去年，隨着美國息率上升，港美息差持續擴闊，「沽港元、買美元」套息活動增加，港元兌美元匯率在年初轉弱，2005年制訂的「弱方兌換保證」，自4月首度觸發後，年內再觸發26次。金管局按照既定機制，履行「買港元、沽美元」的弱方兌換保證，有序、透明地在市場承接1,035億港元的港元沽盤。隨着資金流走，一個月香港銀行同業拆息在2018年內累升了105基點，而銀行亦在去年9月美國加息後，上調了最優惠利率。金管局多次和適時通過不同渠道向公眾闡釋「弱方兌換保證」的運作機制，令公眾了解資金流出港元是香港利率正常化的必經過程，也是聯匯制度的正常運作。國際貨幣基金組織在去年年底重申支持香港聯匯制度的立場，特區政府也強調聯匯是香港貨幣穩定的基石。這都有助於穩定香港市民對聯繫匯率的信心。

# 銀行體系 穩中有進

2008年環球金融危機暴露了全球金融系統潛藏的種種弊端及隱患，促使國際間在過去十年協調推出一系列針對金融市場、金融機構的改革，包括在銀行業監管方面，提升企業管治和風險管理。金管局的銀行監管工作重點針對兩方面：一是着眼於銀行資產負債風險的審慎監管，二是銀行的行為操守，二者不可偏廢。資產負債風險監管方面，金管局作為巴塞爾銀行監管委員會(Basel Committee on Banking Supervision)及二十國集團轄下金融穩定理事會(FinancialStability Board)成員，有責任全面落實國際監管標準，確保香港銀行業穩健審慎地經營業務。去年底香港銀行資本充足率達20.3%，不但遠高於國際最低標準要求的8%，也較環球金融危機時的14.7%水平顯著提升。大型銀行去年第四季平均流動覆蓋比率達167.6%，同樣遠高於法定最低要求的90%。與此同時，為避免重蹈環球金融危機時需動用公帑拯救「大得不能倒」金融機構的覆轍，金融穩定理事會制訂了關於金融機構處置機制的國際標準。香港是亞洲區內少數已經全面落實符合機制要求的地區之一，金管局下設的處置機制辦公室正落實該機制的操作細則，要求銀行推行結構性變動令處置預案在需要時能有效實施，去年亦推出了《吸收虧損能力規則》，未來還會陸續推出更多相關規則。

鑑於樓價持續上升，金管局未雨綢繆，在2009至2017年間共推出八輪逆周期措施，確保一旦地產市況逆轉，本港銀行體系有足夠的抗震能力應對衝擊。這些措施成效顯著：新造住宅平均按揭成數由2009年的64%降至2018年底的46%；平均供款與入息比率亦由2010年的41%下調至2018年底的34%。年內銀行信貸錄得4.4%的溫和增長，整體資產質素維持良好，零售銀行不良貸款比率進一步降至0.5%，遠低於國際及本港歷史平均水平。去年銀行業盈利持續增長，整體股東權益回報率連升兩年至13%；多家國際性銀行集團在本港的業務交出了不俗的成績表，成為集團盈利的重要支柱。

# 穩善文化 上行下效

在監管銀行的行為操守方面，金管局在2010年增設銀行操守部，促進銀行公平待客，並加強保障消費者權益。要做到標本兼治，除了訂出各種針對銀行營運基本操守的監管要求外，我們近年來大力推動改革銀行文化，鼓勵銀行循管治、獎勵制度、評估與回饋機制三方面推動穩善文化，務求銀行內部做到上行下效，在根本上恢復、提升客戶對銀行的信任和尊重。繼2017年金管局向全港銀行提供具體的指引，金管局在2018年底進一步推出銀行文化的監管措施，包括要求銀行就企業文化和落實有關措施作出自我評估等，令穩善銀行文化的三大支柱能有效執行。

雖然互聯網和移動金融是全球趨勢，金管局去年仍繼續促進普及金融，照顧未能應用新科技的社群。例如我們連同香港銀行公會推動便利店推出長者透過「易辦事」免購物提款服務，有關便利店網絡已增至逾300家；我們並聯絡香港郵政在7家主要位於離島和新界的郵政局推出長者提款易服務。銀行業界響應金管局的建議，年內積極增加無障礙設施，提供傷健共融的銀行服務，例子之一是設有聲音導航的自動櫃員機數目一年內增加逾十倍至超過700部。另外，在金管局積極推動下，我們預期將會陸續有銀行在偏遠地區開設更多實體分行和增設流動銀行服務，便利市民。

# 智慧銀行 嶄新體驗

金管局與銀行和科技業界緊密合作，在2017年9月啟動「智慧銀行新紀元」，推動香港金融科技發展和創新，為市民帶來嶄新的支付和銀行服務體驗。2018年的亮點，無疑是在9月正式開通的「轉數快」。它是全球獨一無二的零售快速支付系統，打破香港各種電子支付工具和銀行帳戶之間的屏障，讓市民享受全年無休的港元和人民幣即時轉帳服務。金管局還同步推出全球首個「共用二維碼」標準和應用程式，商戶可憑單個二維碼接通多個電子支付系統。「轉數快」推出以來深受市民歡迎，短短半年，登記紀錄已逾258萬個，日均交易量達6萬宗，平均每宗金額分別20,700港元和38,000元人民幣。

去年5月，金管局發出虛擬銀行的認可指引，隨即有33家機構提交虛擬銀行牌照的申請。截至今年四月中，四個牌照已經發出，預期它們將於年內正式投入營運。虛擬銀行有助推動香港金融科技發展和創新，為個人和中小企提供嶄新服務和體驗，並促進普及金融。

此外，金管局在7月發布開放應用程式介面(OpenAPI)框架，銀行將分四階段開放產品和服務的對外接口，開創更靈活、更開放的金融科技環境，讓銀行客戶更便捷地整合帳戶資料、獲取資訊，選取貼合自己需要的服務。年內，共有42項新科技產品使用金管局的金融科技監管沙盒進行測試，當中28項完成試行，有關產品和服務已順利推出市場。

金管局聯同多家銀行研發的「貿易聯動」去年10月正式啟用，這個採用「分布式分類帳技術」的貿易融資平台，將提升銀行審批貿易融資的效率。「貿易聯動」目前正在測試連接其他地區相關平台，以促進跨境貿易融資活動。

金融科技不但廣泛應用於日常生活，近年更走進合規和監管領域。金管局鼓勵銀行運用合規科技(Regtech)協助處理日常營運如監察涉嫌洗錢和恐怖分子資金籌集的可疑活動。與此同時金管局正研究使用監管科技(Suptech)，進一步提升監管工作的效率和成效。

# 金融實力 鞏固提升

國際金融中心之間是軟實力的較量，我們要不斷順應經濟社會和科技發展的變化，把握機遇，不斷為香港金融業開拓新的發展空間。綠色金融就是香港開拓債券和項目融資市場的一個重大機遇。金管局支持和配合特區政府發展綠色金融，除了配合特區政府籌備1,000億港元的政府綠色債券發行計劃，我們去年還舉辦多場綠色金融研討會，包括兩場國際大型會議，以提升市場對綠色金融的認識、了解和參與，並鼓勵發行機構參與政府去年推出的綠色債券資助計劃和香港的綠色金融認證服務。去年在港發行綠色債券規模逾110億美元，相等於2017年的三倍多。

近年來投資界對基建和相關項目興趣日濃。金管局於2016年成立基建融資促進辦公室(IFFO)，合作夥伴至今已倍增至95家機構，成為區內基建融資的重要交流平台。去年金管局與國務院國有資產監督管理委員會（國資委）首次合辦高層圓桌會議，討論香港為中央國有企業「走出去」的獨特優勢和作用，為央企與香港金融、專業服務界日後共拓發展機遇奠下良好基礎。

en:
# Chairman's Report

2018 was the tenth anniversary of the global financial crisis. Over the past decade, the international political and economic landscape has undergone significant changes, with many scenes that even the best scriptwriters could not have imagined. In last year's annual report, I pointed out that the financial market performance in 2017 was "unexpectedly positive," while also mentioning that the outlook "concealed hidden concerns." Looking back at 2018, it might be described as "started well but ended off-colour." Following the record highs of several global stock indices in January, the euphoric investment sentiment quickly met the cold front of Sino-US trade tensions, along with ongoing Brexit negotiations, deteriorating geopolitical situations, and four interest rate hikes by the Federal Reserve. The optimistic market mood rapidly reversed, leading to significant declines in asset prices throughout the year. The MSCI Global Index fell by as much as 20.3% from its peak to its low point, and declined by about 10% for the year, marking the worst performance since the 2008 global financial crisis. The Hang Seng Index fell by as much as 26.7% from its peak and dropped by 13.6% for the year, recording the largest annual decline in seven years.

# Confidence is Tied to Stable Convergence

Despite the volatility of external conditions, Hong Kong’s financial system remains stable, and the money market operates smoothly. The linked exchange rate system, implemented for 35 years, has successfully withstood the test of capital outflows from the Hong Kong dollar. Since the outbreak of the global financial crisis, approximately HKD 10,000 billion equivalent in funds have flowed into the Hong Kong dollar. Last year, as U.S. interest rates rose, the interest rate differential between Hong Kong and the U.S. continued to widen, leading to an increase in “sell Hong Kong dollars, buy U.S. dollars” arbitrage activities. The Hong Kong dollar exchange rate against the U.S. dollar weakened at the beginning of the year. The “weak-side convertibility guarantee,” established in 2005, was first triggered in April and was triggered another 26 times during the year. The Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA), in accordance with established mechanisms, fulfilled the weak-side convertibility guarantee by “buying Hong Kong dollars and selling U.S. dollars,” and orderly and transparently absorbed HKD 103.5 billion worth of Hong Kong dollar sell orders in the market. As capital flowed out, the one-month Hong Kong interbank offered rate (HIBOR) rose by 105 basis points within 2018, and banks also raised their prime lending rates after the U.S. interest rate hike in September last year. The HKMA repeatedly and appropriately explained the operation mechanism of the “weak-side convertibility guarantee” to the public through various channels, helping the public understand that the outflow of funds from the Hong Kong dollar is an inevitable process of Hong Kong interest rate normalization and the normal operation of the linked exchange rate system. The International Monetary Fund reaffirmed its support for the Hong Kong linked exchange rate system at the end of last year, and the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region government also emphasized that the linked exchange rate is the cornerstone of Hong Kong’s monetary stability. This has helped to stabilize public confidence in the linked exchange rate system.

# Banking System: Stability with Progress

The 2008 global financial crisis exposed various hidden flaws and risks in the global financial system, prompting international coordination over the past decade to implement a series of reforms targeting financial markets and financial institutions, including enhancing corporate governance and risk management in banking supervision. The Hong Kong Monetary Authority's (HKMA) banking supervision focuses on two key areas: one is prudent regulation of banks' balance sheet risks, and the other is the conduct of banks, both of which are equally important. In terms of balance sheet risk regulation, as a member of the Basel Committee on Banking Supervision and the Financial Stability Board under the G20, the HKMA has the responsibility to fully implement international regulatory standards and ensure that Hong Kong's banking sector operates in a sound and prudent manner. At the end of last year, Hong Kong's banking sector had a capital adequacy ratio of 20.3%, which is not only significantly higher than the international minimum standard of 8%, but also notably higher than the 14.7% level during the global financial crisis. The average liquidity coverage ratio of large banks in the fourth quarter of last year reached 167.6%, which is also far above the statutory minimum requirement of 90%. At the same time, to avoid repeating the mistakes of the global financial crisis, where public funds had to be used to rescue "too big to fail" financial institutions, the Financial Stability Board has established international standards for the resolution mechanisms of financial institutions. Hong Kong is one of the few regions in Asia that has fully implemented mechanisms in line with these requirements. The HKMA's Office of Resolution Mechanism is implementing the operational details of this mechanism, requiring banks to make structural changes so that resolution plans can be effectively implemented when needed. Last year, the HKMA also introduced the "Loss Absorption Capacity Rules," and more related rules will be introduced in the future.

Given the continued rise in property prices, the Financial Services and Markets Commission has taken proactive measures, launching a total of eight counter-cyclical measures between 2009 and 2017 to ensure that the local banking system has sufficient resilience to withstand shocks should the property market turn. These measures have been effective: the average mortgage loan-to-value ratio for new residential properties decreased from 64% in 2009 to 46% by the end of 2018; the average debt-to-income ratio also fell from 41% in 2010 to 34% by the end of 2018. Bank lending recorded a moderate growth of 4.4% during the year, overall asset quality remained good, and the retail banking non-performing loan ratio further decreased to 0.5%, far below historical international and local averages. Last year, bank profits continued to grow, with overall return on equity rising for two consecutive years to 13%; several international banking groups achieved impressive results in Hong Kong, becoming important pillars of group profits.

# Steadfast and Kind Culture Leading by Example

In regulating the conduct of banks, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) established the Banking Conduct Division in 2010 to promote fair treatment of customers and strengthen consumer protection. To address both symptoms and root causes, in addition to setting regulatory requirements targeting the fundamental conduct of banking operations, we have actively promoted reforms in banking culture in recent years. We encourage banks to foster a culture of integrity through governance, reward systems, and assessment and feedback mechanisms, ensuring consistent implementation throughout the organization and fundamentally restoring and enhancing customer trust and respect. Following the HKMA's provision of specific guidelines to all banks in Hong Kong in 2017, the HKMA further introduced regulatory measures on banking culture by the end of 2018, including requiring banks to conduct self-assessments on their corporate culture and the implementation of related measures, thereby effectively enforcing the three pillars of a sound banking culture.

Although the Internet and mobile banking are global trends, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) continued to promote financial inclusion last year, taking care of communities that are unable to use new technologies. For example, we worked with the Hong Kong Bankers' Association to encourage convenience stores to offer elderly customers a shopping-free withdrawal service through the "EasyPay" system. The network of such convenience stores has now grown to more than 300. We also contacted Hong Kong Post to introduce the Elderly Withdrawal Service at seven main post offices located in outlying islands and the New Territories. The banking industry has responded positively to the HKMA's recommendations, actively increasing accessibility facilities and providing inclusive banking services for people with disabilities. One example is that the number of automated teller machines equipped with voice navigation has increased more than tenfold within a year, reaching over 700 units. In addition, under the active promotion of the HKMA, we expect banks to gradually open more physical branches and introduce mobile banking services in remote areas, making banking more convenient for the public.

# Smart Bank: A Brand New Experience

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) closely collaborated with banks and the technology industry to launch the "Smart Banking New Era" in September 2017, promoting the development and innovation of Hong Kong's financial technology (fintech) industry and offering citizens a new payment and banking service experience. The highlight of 2018 was undoubtedly the official launch of "Fast Payment System" in September. It is a unique retail fast payment system globally, breaking down barriers between various electronic payment tools and bank accounts in Hong Kong, enabling citizens to enjoy 24/7 real-time HKD and RMB transfers. The HKMA also simultaneously introduced the world's first "shared QR code" standard and application, allowing merchants to connect to multiple electronic payment systems via a single QR code. Since its launch, "Fast Payment System" has been widely welcomed by the public. Within just six months, the number of registered users exceeded 2.58 million, with an average of 60,000 transactions per day, averaging HK$20,700 and RMB 38,000 per transaction respectively.

In May last year, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority issued guidelines for the licensing of virtual banks, and shortly after, 33 institutions submitted applications for virtual bank licenses. As of mid-April this year, four licenses have already been issued, and it is expected that they will officially commence operations within the year. Virtual banks will help promote the development and innovation of financial technology in Hong Kong, provide individuals and small and medium-sized enterprises with new services and experiences, and promote financial inclusion.

Furthermore, the Financial Supervisory Authority released an OpenAPI framework in July, and banks will open external interfaces for their products and services in four phases, creating a more flexible and open fintech environment, allowing bank customers to more conveniently integrate account data, obtain information, and select services that meet their needs. Within the year, a total of 42 new technology products used the Financial Supervisory Authority’s fintech regulatory sandbox for testing, of which 28 completed trials, and these products and services have been successfully launched into the market.

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority, in collaboration with multiple banks, officially launched "TradeLink" in October last year. This trade financing platform, which employs "distributed ledger technology," aims to enhance the efficiency of banks in approving trade financing. "TradeLink" is currently testing connections to relevant platforms in other regions to promote cross-border trade financing activities.

Fintech is not only widely used in daily life but has also entered the fields of compliance and regulation in recent years. The Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) encourages banks to leverage compliance technology (Regtech) to assist in handling daily operations such as monitoring suspicious activities related to money laundering and terrorist financing. At the same time, the HKMA is researching the use of supervisory technology (Suptech) to further enhance the efficiency and effectiveness of regulatory work.

# Consolidate and Enhance Financial Strength

The competition among international financial centers is a contest of soft power. We must continuously adapt to changes in the economic, social, and technological landscape, seize opportunities, and constantly open up new development spaces for Hong Kong's financial industry. Green finance represents a significant opportunity for Hong Kong to develop its bond and project financing markets. The Hong Kong Monetary Authority supports and collaborates with the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region government in developing green finance. In addition to supporting the government's preparation for the issuance plan of HKD 100 billion in government green bonds, we held multiple green finance seminars last year, including two major international conferences, to enhance market understanding, awareness, and participation in green finance, and to encourage issuing institutions to participate in the government's green bond grant scheme launched last year and the green finance certification service in Hong Kong. The amount of green bonds issued in Hong Kong last year exceeded USD 11 billion, which is more than three times that of 2017.

“近年來投資界對基建和相關項目興趣日濃。金管局於2016年成立基建融資促進辦公室(IFFO)，合作夥伴至今已倍增至95家機構，成為區內基建融資的重要交流平台。去年金管局與國務院國有資產監督管理委員會（國資委）首次合辦高層圓桌會議，討論香港為中央國有企業「走出去」的獨特優勢和作用，為央企與香港金融、專業服務界日後共拓發展機遇奠下良好基礎。”
In recent years, the investment community has shown increasing interest in infrastructure and related projects. The Hong Kong Monetary Authority established the Infrastructure Financing Facilitation Office (IFFO) in 2016, and its partners have since more than doubled to 95 institutions, becoming an important exchange platform for infrastructure financing in the region. Last year, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority and the State-owned Assets Supervision and Administration Commission of the State Council (SASAC) co-hosted a high-level roundtable meeting to discuss Hong Kong’s unique advantages and role in supporting central state-owned enterprises’ “going global” strategy, laying a good foundation for future collaboration between central enterprises and the Hong Kong financial and professional services sectors to jointly explore development opportunities.

# 2018年大事紀要

# 貨幣穩定

# 4月12日

金管局7.85港元兌1美元的弱方兌換保證於倫敦交易時段被觸發，這是2005年金管局推出3項優化聯繫匯率制度的措施以來弱方兌換保證首度被觸發。於2018年，弱方兌換保證合共被觸發27次。

# 7月24日

金管局與3間發鈔銀行公布推出2018香港新鈔票系列。

# 10月26日

金管局宣布指定9間認可機構作為香港離岸人民幣市場的一級流動性提供行。

# 銀行體系

# 1月10日

金管局公布由2019年1月1日起，香港適用的逆周期緩衝資本由1.875%上調至2.5%。

# 2月2日

《2018年打擊洗錢及恐怖分子資金籌集（金融機構）（修訂）條例》刊憲。

# 2月28日

金融穩定理事會發出有關香港的同業評審報告，確認香港近年在場外衍生工具市場改革及設立金融機構處置框架方面進展理想。

# 3月23日

金管局促成香港銀行公會發出《無障礙銀行服務實務指引》。

# 5月4日

《2018年銀行業（披露）（修訂）規則》及《2018年銀行業（指明多邊發展銀行）（修訂）公告》刊憲。

# 5月18日

《2018年〈2018年銀行業（修訂）條例〉（生效日期）公告》及《銀行業（風險承擔限度）規則》刊憲。

# 5月30日

金管局在經完成公眾諮詢後發出《虛擬銀行的認可》指引修訂本。

# 10月3日

金管局在香港主辦第2屆獨立非執行董事研討會。

# 10月19日

《金融機構（處置機制）（吸收虧損能力規定—銀行界）規則》（《吸收虧損能力規則》）及相關的《2018年稅務（修訂）（第6號）條例草案》刊憲。

# 10月26日

金管局與澳門金融管理局簽署《合作備忘錄》，共同推行銀行專業資歷架構的專業培訓及資格互認。

# 11月16日

《2018年〈銀行業（修訂）條例〉（生效日期）（第2號）公告》、《銀行業（風險承擔限度）規則》、《2018年銀行業（資本）（修訂）規則》及《2018年銀行業（披露）（修訂）（第2號）規則》刊憲。

# 12月14日

《吸收虧損能力規則》生效。

# 12月19日

金管局推出銀行文化的監管措施（即自我評估、專題評估及銀行文化對話），以了解香港銀行文化改革的進展。

# 12月21日

金管局公布被指定為具本地系統重要性認可機構的最新名單。

# 香港的國際金融中心地位

# 1月23日

金管局與瑞士聯邦財政部簽署《諒解備忘錄》，加強雙方在人民幣國際化、財富管理、基建融資及國際金融事務等方面的金融合作。金管局另與瑞士金融市場監督管理局簽署《諒解備忘錄》，促進兩地金融創新。

# 1月31日

金管局推出「金融科技人才培育計劃」升級版(FCAS 2.0)，旨在加強培育本港金融科技專才，應付業界日益增加的需求。

# 3月9日

金管局與波蘭金融監管局交換《諒解備忘錄》，促進雙方的金融科技合作。

# 3月27-28日

金管局基建融資促進辦公室(IFFO)與國際金融公司及多邊投資擔保機構合辦為期兩日的行政人員工作坊。

# 5月15日

IFFO與香港銀行公會合辦「建設可持續發展的一帶一路：香港的關鍵角色」研討會。

# 5月29日

金管局與投資推廣署在廣州合辦主題為「粵港澳大灣區•海外財資管理新機遇」研討會。

# 6月14日

金管局與國際資本市場協會在香港合辦「2018綠色及社會責任債券原則」年度會員大會及會議。

# 6月15日

金管局與中國人民銀行（人民銀行）研究局在香港合辦「內地與香港綠色金融合作研討會。

# 6月25日

金管局與深圳市人民政府金融發展服務辦公室啟動為香港大專學生而設的首屆「深圳金融科技暑期實習計劃」。

# 6月26日

金管局與阿布扎比國際金融中心金融服務監管局簽署《合作協議》，加強雙方的金融科技合作。

# 6月27日

金管局與證券及期貨事務監察委員會發表有關進一步改善場外衍生工具監管制度的聯合諮詢總結文件。

# 6月28日

IFFO於第3屆「一帶一路高峰論壇」期間主持「基建投融資的風險緩釋」專題討論。

# 7月3日

「債券通」開通一周年。

# 7月18日

金管局發布香港銀行業「開放應用程式界面」（開放API）框架。

# 8月7日

金管局與11間金融監管當局和相關機構公布「全球金融創新網絡」計劃。

# 8月15-16日

金管局與國務院國有資產監督管理委員會在香港合辦「連通一帶一路，共拓發展機遇」高層圓桌會議。

# 8月24日

「債券通」全面實施即時貨銀兩訖(DvP)結算模式。

# 8月31日

金管局根據《支付系統及儲值支付工具條例》（第584章）指定兩個零售支付系統。

# 9月9日

金管局與巴西中央銀行簽署《合作協議》，促進兩間中央銀行在金融科技事項的合作。

# 9月17日

金管局宣布啟動快速支付系統「轉數快」。該系統於9月30日全面啟用。

# 9月20日

金管局與人民銀行簽訂《關於使用債務工具中央結算系統發行中國人民銀行票據的合作備忘錄》。

# 9月21日

由金管局與財資市場公會合辦的「2018財資市場高峰會」在香港舉行。

# 10月25-26日

IFFO舉辦第2屆「投資者及債權融資圓桌會議」，另亦宣布新增5間機構為合作夥伴，使總數增至95間。

# 10月31日

金管局宣布「貿易聯動」正式啟動。這是一 個建基於區塊鏈、由香港12間主要銀行組成的聯盟共同開發的貿易融資平台。

金管局見證由「貿易聯動」與歐洲we.trade兩個平台的營運商簽署《合作諒解備忘錄》，以展開一個新的概念驗證，把兩個平台對接。

# 10月31日至11月15日

金管局就財務行動特別組織及亞洲╱太平洋反清洗黑錢組織對香港聯合進行的相互評估提供實地考察安排。該項評估檢視香港打擊洗錢及恐怖分子資金籌集制度的成效。

# 12月12日

國際貨幣基金組織就香港特別行政區2018年第四條磋商發表初步總結，指出香港多年來一直奉行的審慎宏觀經濟政策，為香港提供強大的緩衝空間以應對挑戰，並讚揚香港維持審慎的金融規管與監管，以及重申其對聯繫匯率制度的支持。

# Summary of Major Events in 2018

# Currency Stability

# April 12th

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority’s weak-side exchange guarantee at 7.85 Hong Kong dollars to 1 U.S. dollar was triggered during the London trading session, marking the first time since the Hong Kong Monetary Authority introduced three measures to optimize the linked exchange rate system in 2005 that the weak-side exchange guarantee has been triggered. In 2018, the weak-side exchange guarantee was triggered a total of 27 times.

# July 24

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) and three note-issuing banks announced the launch of the 2018 Hong Kong New Banknote Series.

# October 26th

The HKMA announced the designation of nine authorized institutions as primary liquidity providers for the offshore RMB market in Hong Kong.

# Banking system

# January 10th

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority announced that, effective January 1, 2019, the countercyclical capital buffer applicable to Hong Kong will be increased from 1.875% to 2.5%.

# February 2nd

The 2018 Anti-Money Laundering and Counter-Terrorist Financing (Financial Institutions) Amendment Ordinance has been gazetted.

# February 28th

The Financial Stability Board issued a peer review report on Hong Kong, confirming that Hong Kong has made good progress in recent years in reforming the over-the-counter derivatives market and establishing a financial institution resolution framework.

# March 23

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority encouraged the Hong Kong Association of Banks to issue the "Practical Guidelines for Accessible Banking Services."

# May 4th

The 2018 revised Banking (Disclosure) Rules and the 2018 revised Banking (Specified Multilateral Development Banks) Notice have been gazetted.

# May 18th

The Notice on the Effective Date of the 2018 Banking (Amendment) Ordinance and the Banking (Risk Exposure Limits) Rules have been gazetted.

# May 30th

The HKMA issued a revised version of the "Licensing of Virtual Banks" guidance following the completion of public consultation.

# October 3rd

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority hosted the 2nd edition of the Independent Non-Executive Directors Seminar in Hong Kong.

# October 19th

The “Financial Institutions (Resolution Mechanism) (Loss-Absorbing Capacity Rules—Banking Sector) Rules” and the related “2018 Tax (Amendment) (No. 6) Bill” have been gazetted.

# October 26th

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority and the Macao Financial Services Bureau signed a Memorandum of Understanding to jointly advance the banking professional qualifications framework through professional training and mutual recognition of qualifications.

# November 16

The "Notice on the Effective Date of the Banking (Amendment) Ordinance (No. 2) 2018", the "Banking (Risk Limitation) Rules", the "Banking (Capital) (Amendment) Rules 2018", and the "Banking (Disclosure) (Amendment) (No. 2) Rules 2018" have been gazetted.

# December 14th

The Absorption Loss Capacity Rules come into operation.

# December 19

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority has launched regulatory initiatives on banking culture – namely self-assessment, thematic reviews, and banking culture dialogue – to understand the progress of banking culture reform in Hong Kong.

# December 21

The HKMA has announced the latest list of institutions recognized as systemically important institutions with local significance.

# Hong Kong's Status as an International Financial Center

# January 23rd

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) and the Swiss Federal Department of Finance signed a Memorandum of Understanding (MOU) to strengthen financial cooperation between the two sides in areas such as RMB internationalisation, wealth management, infrastructure financing and international financial affairs. The HKMA also signed an MOU with the Swiss Financial Market Supervisory Authority to promote financial innovation in both locations.

# January 31st

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority has launched an enhanced version of the "FinTech Talent Development Program" (FCAS 2.0), aiming to strengthen the development of local FinTech professionals to meet the industry's growing demand.

# March 9

The Financial Supervisory Authority exchanged a memorandum of understanding with the Polish Financial Regulatory Authority to promote financial technology cooperation between the two parties.

# March 27-28

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority’s Infrastructure Financing Facilitation Office (IFFO) co-organized a two-day workshop for administrative staff with the International Finance Corporation and the Multilateral Investment Guarantee Agency.

# May 15th

IFFO and the Hong Kong Bankers Association co-hosted a seminar titled "Building a Sustainable Belt and Road Initiative: Hong Kong’s Key Role."

# May 29th

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority and the Hong Kong Investment Promotion Board co-hosted a seminar in Guangzhou with the theme "Guangdong-Hong Kong-Macao Greater Bay Area • New Opportunities in Overseas Wealth Management".

# June 14

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority and the International Capital Market Association co-hosted the "2018 Green and Social Responsibility Bond Principles Annual Members' Meeting and Conference" in Hong Kong.

# June 15th

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) and the Research Bureau of the People's Bank of China (PBOC) co-hosted the "Seminar on Cooperation in Green Finance between Mainland China and Hong Kong" in Hong Kong.

# June 25th

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority and the Financial Development Service Office of the Shenzhen Municipal People's Government have launched the inaugural "Shenzhen Fintech Summer Internship Program" for Hong Kong university students.

# June 26

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority signed a Memorandum of Understanding with the Dubai International Financial Centre Financial Services Regulatory Authority to strengthen cooperation in financial technology between the two parties.

# June 27th

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority and the Securities and Futures Commission have published a joint consultation conclusions paper on further improving the regulatory regime for over-the-counter derivatives.

# June 28th

IFFO hosted a panel discussion on "Risk Mitigation in Infrastructure Investment and Financing" during the 3rd "Belt and Road Summit Forum."

# July 3rd

The "Bond Connect" has been operational for one year.

# July 18th

The HKMA released the "Open Application Programming Interface" (Open API) framework for the banking industry in Hong Kong.

# August 7th

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority, together with 11 financial regulatory authorities and related institutions, announced the "Global Financial Innovation Network" Programme.

# August 15-16

The Financial Services and Markets Authority and the State-owned Assets Supervision and Administration Commission of the State Council co-hosted a high-level roundtable meeting in Hong Kong, titled "Connecting the Belt and Road, Jointly Exploring Development Opportunities."

# August 24

Bond Connect fully implements a real-time delivery versus payment (DvP) settlement model.

# August 31

The HKMA has designated two retail payment systems under the Payment Systems and Stored Value Facilities Ordinance (Chapter 584).

# September 9th

The Financial Supervisory Authority and the Central Bank of Brazil signed a "Cooperation Agreement" to promote cooperation between the two central banks on fintech matters.

# September 17th

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority announced the launch of the fast payment system "TransferFast". The system was fully operational on September 30.

# September 20th

The Financial Services and Markets Authority and the People’s Bank of China signed a memorandum of understanding regarding the issuance of People’s Bank of China notes using the central clearing system for debt instruments.

# September 21

The "2018 Financial Markets Summit", co-organized by the Hong Kong Monetary Authority and the Hong Kong Association of Financial Markets, was held in Hong Kong.

# October 25-26

IFFO held the 2nd "Investors and Credit Financing Roundtable Meeting" and also announced the addition of five new institutions as partners, bringing the total number to 95.

# October 31st

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority announced the official launch of "TradeLink". It is a trade financing platform based on blockchain technology, jointly developed by a consortium of 12 major Hong Kong banks.

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority witnessed the signing of a Memorandum of Understanding between the operators of the "TradeLink" and European we.trade platforms, to launch a new proof-of-concept project to connect the two platforms.

# From October 31 to November 15

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority is providing on-site visit arrangements for the Financial Action Task Force and the Asia/Pacific Group on Money Laundering’s joint evaluation of Hong Kong. This evaluation reviews the effectiveness of Hong Kong’s systems for combating money laundering and terrorist financing.

# December 12th

The International Monetary Fund (IMF) released a preliminary summary of its 2018 Article IV consultation with the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region, noting that Hong Kong's long-standing prudent macroeconomic policies have provided the territory with strong buffer space to cope with challenges. The IMF also praised Hong Kong's maintenance of prudent financial regulation and supervision, and reiterated its support for Hong Kong's linked exchange rate system.

zh:
# 金管局簡介

香港金融管理局是香港的中央銀行機構，主要職能有4項：在聯繫匯率制度的架構內維持貨幣穩定；促進金融體系（包括銀行體系）的穩定與健全；協助鞏固香港的國際金融中心地位，包括維持與發展香港的金融基建；以及管理外匯基金。

# 金管局的法定授權

立法會（前稱立法局）於1992年通過《外匯基金條例》修訂條文，授權財政司司長（前稱財政司）委任金融管理專員，金管局隨後在1993年4月1日成立。

金融管理專員的權力、職能及責任由《外匯基金條例》、《銀行業條例》、《金融機構（處置機制）條例》、《存款保障計劃條例》、《支付系統及儲值支付工具條例》及其他有關條例明文規定。財政司司長與金融管理專員於2003年6月25日的互換函件，列載彼此在貨幣與金融事務方面的職能與責任的分配，亦披露財政司司長將若干權力轉授金融管理專員。有關函件為公開文件，可於金管局網站查閱。

外匯基金根據《外匯基金條例》設立，由財政司司長掌有控制權。該條例規定外匯基金須主要運用於影響港元匯價。財政司司長亦可運用外匯基金以保持香港貨幣金融體系的穩定與健全，藉此保持香港作為國際金融中心的地位。

金融管理專員根據《外匯基金條例》委任，以協助財政司司長執行其根據該條例獲授予的職能，以及執行其他條例及財政司司長所指派的職能。金融管理專員的辦公室稱為金管局，金融管理專員即為金管局總裁。

金融管理專員根據《銀行業條例》賦予的職責及權力，規管及監管銀行業務與接受存款業務。根據《銀行業條例》，金融管理專員負責處理香港持牌銀行、有限制牌照銀行及接受存款公司的認可資格事宜。

《金融機構（處置機制）條例》指定金融管理專員為銀行界實體的處置機制當局。該條例賦予金融管理專員一系列權力，對有關實體進行有秩序處置，以減低有關實體不可持續經營對香港金融體系的穩定及有效運作構成的風險。

《證券及期貨條例》及《強制性公積金計劃條例》賦予金融管理專員若干有關銀行證券及強制性公積金業務的權力。

《保險業條例》訂明可就銀行的保險業務向金融管理專員轉授查察及調查權力。

《打擊洗錢及恐怖分子資金籌集條例》賦權金融管理專員監管銀行遵守該條例的規定。

《存款保障計劃條例》授予金融管理專員責任，就存款保障計劃的運作提供協助，以及啟動從存款保障計劃基金向無力償付銀行的存款人發放補償。

金融管理專員在《支付系統及儲值支付工具條例》的法定架構下，可指定及監察對香港貨幣或金融穩定或對香港發揮作為國際金融中心的功能事關重要的結算及交收系統。該條例亦授權金融管理專員管理儲值支付工具發牌制度，及指定零售支付系統並監察該等系統的運作是否安全及有效率。

# 金管局與香港特別行政區政府

金管局是香港特別行政區政府架構的一部分，但可以按與公務員不同的聘用條款聘請員工，以吸引具適當經驗與專門知識的人才。金管局總裁及其員工均為公職人員。金管局的日常運作，在金融管理專員所獲賦予或轉授的法定權力範圍內高度自主。

財政司司長負責釐定香港的貨幣政策目標及貨幣體制：財政司司長於2003年6月25日致金融管理專員的函件中，訂明應透過貨幣發行局制度維持貨幣穩定，將港元匯率保持在約7.80港元兌1美元的水平。金融管理專員須自行負責達成貨幣政策目標，包括決定有關的策略、工具及執行方式，並負責維持香港貨幣制度的穩定與健全。

財政司司長在財經事務及庫務局局長的協助下，負責維持香港金融體系穩定與健全，以及保持香港的國際金融中心地位的政策。為推行這些政策，金融管理專員的職責包括：
- 促進銀行體系的整體穩定與有效運作
- 與其他有關機構與組織合作，發展債務市場
- 處理與法定紙幣及硬幣的發行及流通有關的事宜
- 透過發展支付、結算及交收系統，以及在適當情況下負責操作有關系統，促進金融基建的安全與效率
- 與其他有關機構與組織合作，促進對香港貨幣及金融體系的信心，並推行適當的發展市場措施，以協助加強香港金融服務的國際競爭力。

外匯基金由財政司司長掌有控制權。金融管理專員須根據財政司司長轉授的權力，就外匯基金的運用及投資管理向財政司司長負責。

# 問責性與透明度

就日常運作及推行政府政策目標所採用的方法，金管局一直保持高度自主，並同時輔以高問責性及透明度。

金管局致力促進貨幣與銀行體系穩定，有效管理官方儲備，發展與監察穩健及多元化的金融基建，從而鞏固香港的國際金融中心地位，推動香港經濟發展。

金管局要有效履行職責，便必須取得社會人士的信心。因此，金管局以嚴謹的態度，履行向公眾解釋其政策及工作的責任，並盡力處理社會上備受關注而涉及金管局職責範圍的事項。

金融管理專員由財政司司長委任，因此金管局透過財政司司長向公眾負責；而由於金管局的職權由立法會通過的法律制訂，因此金管局亦透過立法會向公眾負責。此外，金管局亦明白本身肩負更廣泛的責任，就是促進公眾對金管局角色及目標的認識，並密切留意社會人士所關注的事項。金管局在執行日常工作及與社會保持廣泛聯繫時，堅守盡力提高透明度及保持開放的政策。這項政策有兩大目標：
- 在顧及市場敏感性、商業秘密及機密資料披露的法定限制下，盡量使金融界及公眾充分了解金管局的工作；
- 確保金管局掌握社會脈搏，並對公眾意見作出適當回應。

金管局在透明度方面致力達致國際最高標準，與傳媒保持廣泛聯繫之餘，亦出版各種中英文期刊及專題刊物。金管局的雙語網站(www.hkma.gov.hk)除有專門環節列載經濟研究、統計資料、消費者資訊及其他課題外，還載有金管局出版的刊物、新聞稿、演辭及簡報會資料文件。此外，金管局又利用社交媒體平台，以能在數碼時代中更有效與公眾溝通。金管局辦事處設有資訊中心，分為圖書館及展覽館兩部分，每星期開放6日予公眾參觀及使用。金管局亦舉辦公眾教育活動，透過講座及資訊中心導賞服務，向公眾人士（特別是學生）講解金管局的工作，以及增進市民的金融知識。有關金管局的傳媒聯繫工作、刊物及公眾教育活動的詳細資料，見「機構職能」一章。

金管局公布外匯基金及貨幣發行局帳目資料的次數，一直逐步增加，內容亦越趨詳細。金管局於1999年開始參與國際貨幣基金組織的中央銀行「數據公布特殊標準」計劃。金管局亦公布外匯基金諮詢委員會轄下貨幣發行委員會的會議紀錄，以及貨幣發行局制度運作報告。自1996年起，金管局網站亦載有銀行業監管政策及指引。

金管局與立法會的關係對提高問責性及透明度非常重要。金管局總裁承諾每年3次向立法會財經事務委員會簡報金管局各項工作及政策，並回答有關查詢。此外，金管局代表亦會不時出席立法會財經事務委員會及法案委員會會議，闡釋及商討特別事項，以及協助議員審閱條例草案。

# 諮詢委員會及其他委員會

# 外匯基金諮詢委員會

財政司司長行使外匯基金的控制權時，會聽取外匯基金諮詢委員會的意見。外匯基金諮詢委員會根據《外匯基金條例》第3(1)條成立。該項條文訂明財政司司長行使對外匯基金的控制權時，須諮詢外匯基金諮詢委員會的意見。財政司司長為外匯基金諮詢委員會的當然主席，其他委員（包括金融管理專員）則以個人身分，由財政司司長根據香港特別行政區行政長官的授權委任。委員因各具專業知識及經驗而獲委任，他們的加入讓外匯基金諮詢委員會廣受裨益。委員的專業知識及經驗涵蓋貨幣、金融、經濟、投資、會計、管理、商業及法律等範疇。

外匯基金諮詢委員會下設5個專責委員會，負責監察金管局特定環節的工作，並透過外匯基金諮詢委員會向財政司司長報告及提出建議。外匯基金諮詢委員會在2018年共舉行5次會議，討論各項與金管局工作有關的事宜，其中大部分事項均由有關的專責委員會事先進行討論。

管治委員會監察金管局的表現，以及就金管局薪酬與服務條件、人力資源政策、財政預算、行政及管治事務，向外匯基金諮詢委員會提出建議。該委員會在2018年共召開5次會議，內容涵蓋金管局的開支預算、表現評估、年度薪酬檢討及策略性規劃事宜。該委員會亦審議金管局定期提交的工作報告。

審核委員會檢討金管局的財政匯報程序，並評核其內部管控制度是否足夠和有效，以及提交報告。審核委員會負責檢視金管局的財務報表，編製該等報表的組成項目與會計原則，並聯同外部及內部審計師查核其審計範疇與結果。審核委員會各委員在金管局並沒有任何行政職能。該委員會在2018年共召開2次會議，並審議風險委員會及內部審核處的工作報告。

貨幣發行委員會監察貨幣發行局制度的運作，並匯報這個作為香港聯繫匯率制度支柱的情況。該委員會負責確保貨幣發行局制度按照既定政策運作、提出改進該制度的建議，以及確保該制度的運作維持高透明度。金管局定期公布貨幣發行委員會的會議紀錄及提交該委員會的貨幣發行局制度運作報告。該委員會在2018年共召開4次會議。

# Hong Kong Monetary Authority Overview

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority is Hong Kong's central banking institution, with four main functions: maintaining monetary stability within the framework of the linked exchange rate system; promoting the stability and soundness of the financial system (including the banking system); assisting in strengthening Hong Kong's status as an international financial center, including maintaining and developing Hong Kong's financial infrastructure; and managing the foreign exchange fund.

# Statutory Authority of the Hong Kong Monetary Authority

The Legislative Council (previously known as the Legislative Council) passed amendments to the Exchange Fund Ordinance in 1992, authorizing the Financial Secretary (previously known as the Financial Commissioner) to appoint the Financial Management Officer. The Hong Kong Monetary Authority was subsequently established on April 1, 1993.

The powers, functions, and responsibilities of the Financial Secretary and the Chief Executive of the Hong Kong Monetary Authority are explicitly stipulated in the Exchange Fund Ordinance, the Banking Ordinance, the Financial Institutions (Resolution Mechanism) Ordinance, the Deposit Protection Scheme Ordinance, the Payment Systems and Stored Value Facilities Ordinance, and other relevant ordinances. A letter exchanged between the Financial Secretary and the Chief Executive of the Hong Kong Monetary Authority on June 25, 2003, outlines the allocation of their respective functions and responsibilities in monetary and financial matters, and also discloses that the Financial Secretary has delegated certain powers to the Chief Executive of the Hong Kong Monetary Authority. The letter is a public document and is available on the Hong Kong Monetary Authority's website.

The Exchange Fund was established under the Exchange Fund Ordinance and is controlled by the Financial Secretary. The Ordinance stipulates that the Exchange Fund shall primarily be used for influencing the exchange rate of the Hong Kong dollar. The Financial Secretary may also use the Exchange Fund to maintain the stability and integrity of the monetary and financial system of Hong Kong, thereby preserving Hong Kong’s position as an international financial centre.

The Financial Secretary appoints the Financial Controller under the Exchange Fund Ordinance to assist the Financial Secretary in performing the functions conferred upon him by that Ordinance, as well as other functions assigned by the Financial Secretary under other Ordinances. The office of the Financial Controller is known as the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA), and the Financial Controller is the Chief Executive of the HKMA.

The Commissioner of Banking regulates and supervises banking and deposit-taking businesses in accordance with the duties and powers conferred by the Banking Ordinance. Under the Banking Ordinance, the Commissioner of Banking is responsible for handling matters relating to the eligibility for recognition of licensed banks, restricted licensed banks, and deposit-taking companies in Hong Kong.

The Financial Institutions (Resolution Mechanism) Ordinance designates the Financial Services Regulatory Authority as the resolution authority for banking entities. The Ordinance grants the Financial Services Regulatory Authority a series of powers to orderly resolve relevant entities, thereby reducing the risks to the stability and effective operation of Hong Kong's financial system posed by the unsustainable operations of such entities.

The Securities and Futures Ordinance and the Mandatory Provident Fund Schemes Ordinance grant the Financial Services Commissioner certain powers relating to banking, securities, and mandatory provident fund operations.

The Insurance Ordinance stipulates that the power of inspection and investigation regarding banks’ insurance business may be delegated to financial controllers.

The Anti-Money Laundering and Counter-Terrorist Financing Ordinance empowers the Financial Services Authority to oversee banks to ensure adherence to the Ordinance’s provisions.

The Deposit Protection Scheme Ordinance grants the Financial Secretary the responsibility of providing assistance in the operation of the deposit protection scheme, as well as initiating the payment of compensation to depositors of insolvent banks from the deposit protection scheme fund.

The Financial Secretary, under the statutory framework of the Payment Systems and Stored Value Facility Instruments Ordinance, has the authority to designate and supervise settlement and clearing systems that are important for the stability of Hong Kong's currency or financial system, or for Hong Kong's role as an international financial center. The Ordinance also empowers the Financial Secretary to manage the licensing regime for stored value facility instruments, and to designate retail payment systems and supervise whether the operation of such systems is safe and efficient.

# The Hong Kong Monetary Authority and the Government of the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority is part of the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region government structure, but it may hire staff under terms different from those applicable to civil servants to attract individuals with appropriate experience and expertise. The Chief Executive of the Hong Kong Monetary Authority and its staff are public officials. The Hong Kong Monetary Authority's daily operations enjoy a high degree of autonomy within the legal powers conferred or delegated by the Financial Secretary.

The Financial Secretary is responsible for determining Hong Kong’s monetary policy objectives and monetary system. In a letter dated June 25, 2003, addressed to the Hong Kong Monetary Authority, the Financial Secretary stipulated that monetary stability should be maintained through the currency board system, keeping the Hong Kong dollar exchange rate at approximately HK$7.80 to US$1. The Hong Kong Monetary Authority is independently responsible for achieving monetary policy objectives, including determining relevant strategies, tools, and methods of implementation, and for maintaining the stability and soundness of Hong Kong’s monetary system.

The Financial Secretary, with the assistance of the Chief Executive of the Financial Services and Treasury Bureau, is responsible for maintaining the stability and soundness of Hong Kong's financial system and preserving Hong Kong's status as an international financial center. To implement these policies, the duties of the Financial Management Officer include:
- Promoting the overall stability and efficient operation of the banking system
- Collaborating with other relevant institutions and organizations to develop the debt market
- Handling matters related to the issuance and circulation of legal tender notes and coins
- Promoting the security and efficiency of financial infrastructure by developing payment, settlement, and clearing systems, and operating such systems when appropriate
- Collaborating with other relevant institutions and organizations to enhance confidence in Hong Kong's currency and financial system, and implementing appropriate market development measures to help strengthen Hong Kong's international competitiveness in financial services.

The Exchange Fund is under the control of the Financial Secretary. The Financial Management Officer must be accountable to the Financial Secretary for the use and investment management of the Exchange Fund, based on powers delegated by the Financial Secretary.

# Accountability and Transparency

The Financial Supervisory Commission has consistently maintained a high degree of autonomy in its operational practices and the methods employed to achieve government policy objectives, while also being supported by high accountability and transparency.

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority is dedicated to promoting the stability of the currency and banking system, effectively managing official reserves, developing and overseeing a robust and diversified financial infrastructure, thereby consolidating Hong Kong's status as an international financial center and promoting Hong Kong's economic development.

In order to effectively perform its duties, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) must gain the confidence of the public. Therefore, the HKMA adopts a rigorous approach in explaining its policies and operations to the public, and makes every effort to address issues of public concern that fall within its responsibilities.

The Financial Management Officer is appointed by the Financial Secretary, hence the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) is accountable to the public through the Financial Secretary; and since the HKMA's authority is established by laws passed by the Legislative Council, the HKMA is also accountable to the public through the Legislative Council. Additionally, the HKMA is aware of its broader responsibilities, which include promoting public understanding of the HKMA's role and objectives, and closely monitoring issues of public concern. While carrying out daily operations and maintaining extensive connections with society, the HKMA adheres to policies aimed at enhancing transparency and maintaining an open approach. This policy has two main objectives: 
- To fully inform the financial sector and the public about the HKMA's work, taking into account market sensitivity, commercial secrets, and legal restrictions on the disclosure of confidential information; 
- To ensure the HKMA stays attuned to societal trends and appropriately responds to public opinions.

The HKMA is committed to achieving the highest international standards in transparency and maintains extensive media relations while also publishing a variety of Chinese and English periodicals and special publications. The HKMA’s bilingual website (www.hkma.gov.hk) features dedicated sections listing economic research, statistical data, consumer information, and other topics, as well as publications, press releases, speeches, and briefing materials. Furthermore, the HKMA utilizes social media platforms to communicate more effectively with the public in the digital age. The HKMA’s office houses an information center, which is divided into a library and an exhibition hall, and is open to the public for visits and use six days a week. The HKMA also organizes public education activities, explaining the work of the HKMA and enhancing the public’s financial knowledge through seminars and information center guided tours, particularly for students. Detailed information regarding the HKMA’s media relations, publications, and public education activities can be found in the chapter “Institutional Functions.”

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) has progressively increased the frequency of its disclosures regarding the accounts of the Exchange Fund and the Currency Issuance Department, with the content becoming increasingly detailed. The HKMA joined the International Monetary Fund's (IMF) Central Bank "Data Dissemination Special Standard" Programme in 1999. It also publishes the minutes of meetings of the Currency Issuing Committee under the Exchange Fund Advisory Committee, as well as reports on the operation of the Currency Issuance Department system. Since 1996, the HKMA website has also featured banking supervision policies and guidelines.

The relationship between the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) and the Legislative Council is crucial for enhancing accountability and transparency. The HKMA Governor has committed to providing briefings to the Financial Affairs Committee of the Legislative Council on the HKMA's operations and policies three times a year, and to answer relevant inquiries. In addition, HKMA representatives will occasionally attend meetings of the Financial Affairs Committee and the Bills Committee of the Legislative Council to explain and discuss specific matters, and assist members in reviewing draft legislation.

# Advisory committees and other committees

# Foreign Exchange Fund Advisory Committee

The Financial Secretary consults the Exchange Fund Advisory Committee when exercising control over the Exchange Fund. The Exchange Fund Advisory Committee was established under section 3(1) of the Exchange Fund Ordinance. That provision stipulates that the Financial Secretary must consult the Exchange Fund Advisory Committee when exercising control over the Exchange Fund. The Financial Secretary is the ex-officio chairman of the Exchange Fund Advisory Committee, and other members (including the Commissioner for Financial management) are appointed by the Financial Secretary individually, under the authorization of the Chief Executive of the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region. Members are appointed because of their respective professional knowledge and experience, and their participation benefits the Exchange Fund Advisory Committee greatly. The professional knowledge and experience of the members cover areas such as currency, finance, economic, investment, accounting, management, business, and law.

The Exchange Fund Advisory Committee has five specialized committees responsible for overseeing specific aspects of the Hong Kong Monetary Authority's work, and they report and make recommendations to the Financial Secretary through the Exchange Fund Advisory Committee. In 2018, the Exchange Fund Advisory Committee held five meetings to discuss various matters related to the Hong Kong Monetary Authority's work, with most of these matters having been previously discussed by the relevant specialized committees.

The Governance Committee oversees the performance of the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) and makes recommendations to the Hong Kong Exchange Fund Advisory Committee on matters such as the HKMA's remuneration and service conditions, human resources policies, financial budget, and administrative and governance matters. The Committee held five meetings in 2018, covering topics including the HKMA's expenditure budget, performance evaluation, annual salary review, and strategic planning. The Committee also reviews the HKMA's regular work reports.

The Audit Committee reviews the Hong Kong Monetary Authority's (HKMA) financial reporting procedures and evaluates the adequacy and effectiveness of its internal control systems, as well as submits reports. The Audit Committee is responsible for examining the HKMA's financial statements, the components of those statements, and the accounting principles used in their preparation, and works together with external and internal auditors to review the scope and results of the audits. The members of the Audit Committee have no administrative functions within the HKMA. The Committee held two meetings in 2018 and reviewed the work reports of the Risk Committee and the Internal Audit Department.

The Monetary Policy Committee monitors the operations of the Monetary Issue Department System and reports on the situation of this system as a pillar of the Hong Kong Linked Exchange Rate System. The committee is responsible for ensuring that the Monetary Issue Department System operates in accordance with established policies, proposing improvements to the system, and ensuring that the system's operations maintain high transparency. The Hong Kong Monetary Authority regularly publishes the meeting minutes of the Monetary Policy Committee and the operational reports on the Monetary Issue Department System submitted to the committee. The committee held four meetings in 2018.

# 經濟及金融環境

2018年香港經濟持續擴張，不過隨着金融狀況收緊及貿易保護主義升溫令不明朗因素增加，增長動力於年內有所減弱。隨着全球經濟增長轉弱，預期2019年香港經濟增長亦會減慢。

# 經濟回顧

# 實體經濟活動

2018年香港經濟進一步擴張，不過按年增長速度由第1季的4.6%，逐步減慢至第4季的1.3%（表1），並拖累全年增長率由2017年的3.8%下降至3.0%。經濟擴張轉弱，反映本地需求增長減慢以及經濟持續受淨出口所拖累（圖1）。本地方面，私人消費在第1季強勁增長，但其後增長動力減弱，部分反映貿易保護主義升溫令不明朗因素增加，以及本地資產價格調整帶來的財富減值效應。由於營商信心脆弱，整體投資支出的增長速度亦放緩。外圍方面，貨品出口於首3季大致保持平穩，但在第4季隨着中美貿易摩擦加劇而顯著轉差。貨品進口亦因為出口帶動的需求轉弱而放緩。相比之下，服務輸出錄得較快的全年增長，部分是受惠於訪港旅遊業表現蓬勃，而服務輸入則由於運輸、商業及其他服務增長而得以大致維持增長動力。按淨額計，貿易差額由2017年的順差轉為2018年的小幅逆差，並拖累本地經濟增長。

表1 按開支項目計的實質本地生產總值增長（比對上期）

註：本地固定資本形成總額經季節因素調整的按季增減幅度不詳。
資料來源：政府統計處。

圖1 組成部分對實質本地生產總值增長的貢獻
資料來源：政府統計處。

# 貨幣狀況

主要受到港元與美元負息差下的套息活動所影響，港元兌美元匯率在2018年大致回軟。尤其弱方兌換保證在4月、5月及8月被觸發，促使金管局按照聯繫匯率制度（聯匯制度）所定，在7.85港元兌1美元的水平，向銀行購入港元及沽出美元。按照聯匯制度的設計，港元貨幣基礎因而收縮，表示銀行同業流動性減少，再加上市場預期美國加息，導致港元銀行同業拆息整體上升。由於銀行體系資金成本上升，銀行於9月下旬在美國聯邦基金利率目標區間上調後，調高最優惠貸款利率12.5至25基點。信貸增長方面，部分由於本地經濟增長放緩以及對外貿易表現轉弱，整體銀行貸款的增幅由2017年的16.1%，顯著減慢至2018年的4.4%。

# 通脹

通脹壓力於2018年略為增加。剔除政府一次性紓緩措施的影響後，基本通脹率由2017年的1.7%低位，升至2018年的2.6%，不過仍屬於溫和水平。當中的住屋租金組成項目增幅較快，反映較早前新簽訂私人住宅租金上升的影響（圖2）。更廣泛的分析顯示，名義勞工成本及商用物業租金增長略為加快，令本地成本壓力更趨明顯。隨着香港部分主要進口來源地通脹上升，進口價格通脹亦因而攀升。

圖2 基本消費物價通脹
資料來源：政府統計處。

# 勞工市場

勞工市場狀況在2018年保持穩健（圖3）。失業率由2017年全年的3.1%下降至2018年的2.8%，是自1997年以來的最低水平。當中大部分主要服務行業的失業率都有所回落，特別是住宿及膳食服務業的跌幅更為顯著。隨着總就業人數及私營機構職位空缺進一步增加，整體勞工需求持續增強，而且勞動人口參與率亦輕微上升。在勞工市場狀況趨緊下，實質工資及收入進一步增加。

圖3 勞工市場狀況
資料來源：政府統計處。

# 股市

香港股市走勢在2018年大幅逆轉。恒生指數在2017年強勁的上升動力帶動下，於2018年1月升上33,484點的歷史高位（圖4）。然而，隨着主要中央銀行收緊貨幣政策、中美貿易摩擦加劇及本地經濟增長放緩引起投資者的憂慮，市場的樂觀情緒急劇逆轉。恒生指數在10月下挫至24,586點的低位，在年底則收報25,846點，較一年前下跌13.6%。然而，平均每日成交額則由2017年的882億港元上升至1,074億港元，本港首次公開招股集資總額亦因數間從事新興及創科產業的企業上市而大幅增加。

圖4 資產價格
資料來源：差餉物業估價署及香港交易及結算所有限公司。

# 物業市場

住宅物業市場在2018年上半年保持暢旺，不過在下半年隨着中美貿易摩擦加劇、環球股市調整及本港最優惠利率上升而有所降溫。整體樓價在7月至12月期間由高位回落9%，然而全年計仍錄得2%的升幅（圖4）。由於一手及二手市場的買賣活動於下半年顯著減少，所以物業成交量在2018年亦較前一年下跌7%至57,247宗。此外，置業負擔能力仍然偏緊，樓價與收入比率以及收入槓桿比率分別為17.0及75.7，兩者均遠高於長期平均水平。另一方面，非住宅物業價格在2018年整體上升，惟接近年底時稍見回落。全年計，價格及租金均進一步上升，租金回報率則維持在低位。

# 經濟前景

# 經濟環境

由於全球經濟增長放緩，預期2019年香港經濟增長將會減慢。尤其外圍環境充滿挑戰，預期香港出口表現仍會受壓。本地方面，雖然失業率低企及家庭收入增加將繼續支撐私人消費，但部分由於消費信心減弱及較早前的資產價格調整帶來的財富減值效應的影響，預期私人消費增長步伐會放緩。固定資本形成方面，雖然隨着房屋供應增加，樓宇及建造活動應會穩步增長，但面對經濟不明朗因素增加，企業對於資本投資可能會變得更為審慎。政府預測2019年實質本地生產總值增長率介乎2至3%之間，私營機構分析員的最新預測增幅則平均為2.3%。

# 通脹及勞工市場

由於包括香港在內的全球增長放緩，外圍物價及本地成本壓力或會得到紓緩，因此預期通脹壓力在2019年仍保持溫和。近期新簽訂住宅租金回落，亦會對通脹產生壓抑作用。市場共識預測2019年整體通脹率為2.2%，政府預期基本通脹率則為2.5%。預期在經濟持續增長及訪港旅遊業維持暢旺下，勞工市場狀況會繼續偏緊。私營機構分析員預計失業率於2019年會維持於約3%的水平。

# 不明朗因素及風險

2019年經濟前景受貿易摩擦、美國貨幣政策未來方向、內地經濟表現、英國脫歐及其他地緣政治局勢等不明朗因素及風險所影響。另外，一旦上述的不明朗因素加劇並長期持續，金融市場情緒及營商信心或會大受影響，對本地資產市場及實體經濟活動構成下行壓力。

另外，住宅物業市場受眾多外圍及本地因素所影響，其前景並不明朗。外圍方面，中美貿易摩擦的不確定性將有可能影響市場情緒、經濟前景及金融狀況，使香港物業市場前景繼續蒙上陰影。本地方面，雖然經濟增長放緩，但就業情況及收入增長仍大致穩定，或可支持住宅物業需求。本港利率的走勢某程度上視乎美國未來的政策利率變動，惟後者走勢並不明確。長遠而言，由於過去幾年住宅落成量有所增加，加上政府致力增加土地及房屋供應，預期房屋供求缺口或會收窄。

# 銀行體系表現

儘管外圍不利因素增加，例如中美貿易衝突、英國脫歐及利率正常化，令金融市場波動加劇，香港銀行體系在2018年仍然穩健。銀行體系的資本及流動性狀況穩健，資產質素保持良好。利率趨升令息差擴闊，刺激銀行盈利顯著增加。

# 資產負債表走勢

2018年銀行體系繼續穩步增長，資產負債表擴大5.9%。面對經濟不明朗因素持續，例如主要經濟體之間的貿易衝突及加息等，企業在獲取新貸款方面變得較為保守。年內貸款總額增幅放緩至4.4%，而2017年為16.1%。有關增長受在香港使用的貸款（+6.5%）及在香港境外使用的貸款（+2%）同告增加帶動。另一方面，由於環球貿易環境不明朗，貿易融資下跌7.6%。中國內地相關貸款的增長亦由2017年的17.5%放緩至2018年的1.4%。

銀行體系持有的債務證券總額在2018年底繼續佔總資產的22%，與2017年一樣。由於這些債務證券大部分為政府及銀行發行的投資級別債務證券，因此有關信用風險維持在低水平。

就負債方而言，存款總額在2018年增加5%，較2017年（+8.7%）的增幅小。由於預期美國持續加息，部分銀行上調定期存款利率，吸引存戶將往來及儲蓄存款轉為定期存款，從而鎖定資金。往來及儲蓄存款佔存款總額的比例由對上一年的57.4%，降至2018年底的51.4%，導致資金成本上升。由於存款總額的增長較貸款總額快，整體貸存比率由2017年底的73%稍降至2018年底的72.6%（圖5）。

圖5 銀行體系的貸款及存款

# 資本充足水平

銀行體系資本相當充裕，表示其具備強大緩衝以抵禦潛在衝擊。資本比率處於自實施《巴塞爾協定三》以來的歷史高位；本地註冊認可機構的綜合總資本比率由2017年底的19.1%，增加至2018年底的20.3%（圖6）。

圖6 本地註冊認可機構的綜合資本比率

《巴塞爾協定三》槓桿比率於2018年1月1日生效；該比率是一項非風險為本規定，旨在限制銀行體系過度累積槓桿。於2018年底，槓桿比率為8.0%，遠高於3%的法定最低要求（圖7）。

圖7 本地註冊認可機構的綜合槓桿比率

# 流動性狀況

銀行體系的流動性狀況維持穩健，反映其具備強大能力，可有效承受來自潛在金融及經濟壓力的衝擊。短期流動性（涵蓋1個月期資金）方面，第1類機構的平均流動性覆蓋比率在第4季為167.6%，遠高於2018年適用的90%法定最低要求。第2類機構的平均流動性維持比率為54.3%，亦遠高於25%的法定最低要求（圖8）。

# Economic and financial environment

Hong Kong’s economy continued to expand in 2018, but as financial conditions tightened and trade protectionism heated up, uncertainties increased, and growth momentum weakened during the year. With the global economy slowing, it is expected that Hong Kong’s economic growth will also slow in 2019.

# Economic Review

# Real Economic Activities

Hong Kong's economy expanded in 2018, but the annual growth rate slowed from 4.6% in the first quarter to 1.3% in the fourth quarter (Table 1), pulling the full-year growth rate down from 3.8% in 2017 to 3.0%. This deceleration reflected slower growth in local demand and the continued impact of net exports. Locally, private consumption grew strongly in the first quarter, but momentum weakened subsequently, partly due to increased uncertainty stemming from rising trade protectionism and the effect of local asset price adjustments on wealth. Fragile business confidence also contributed to a slowdown in overall investment expenditure. Externally, merchandise exports remained stable for the first three quarters but deteriorated significantly in the fourth quarter as Sino-US trade tensions escalated. Merchandise imports also slowed as demand driven by exports weakened. In contrast, service exports recorded faster annual growth, partly benefiting from the robust performance of the tourism sector, while service imports maintained growth momentum largely due to expansion in transport, commercial, and other services. On a net basis, the trade balance shifted from a surplus in 2017 to a small deficit in 2018, which dampened local economic growth.

Table 1 Real Gross Domestic Product Growth (Compared to Previous Period) by Expenditure Item

Note: The seasonally adjusted quarterly increase or decrease in the total amount of locally fixed capital formation is not detailed.
Source of data: Census and Statistics Department.

Figure 1 Contribution of components to real local gross domestic product growth.
Source: Government Statistics Department.

# Currency status.

The Hong Kong dollar exchange rate against the US dollar generally weakened in 2018, primarily due to carry trade activities driven by the negative interest rate differential between the Hong Kong dollar and the US dollar. In particular, the weak-side exchange guarantee was triggered in April, May, and August, prompting the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) to purchase Hong Kong dollars and sell US dollars at the level of 7.85 Hong Kong dollars to 1 US dollar, as stipulated by the Linked Exchange Rate System (LETS). According to the design of the LETS, the Hong Kong dollar monetary base consequently contracted, indicating reduced interbank liquidity. Combined with market expectations of US interest rate hikes, this led to an overall increase in Hong Kong interbank offered rates. Due to rising funding costs in the banking system, banks raised their prime lending rates by 12.5 to 25 basis points in late September following the upward adjustment of the US Federal Funds rate target range. In terms of credit growth, partly due to slower local economic growth and weaker external trade performance, the overall growth rate of bank loans significantly slowed from 16.1% in 2017 to 4.4% in 2018.

# Inflation

Inflationary pressure slightly increased in 2018. Excluding the impact of one-off government relief measures, the underlying inflation rate rose from 1.7% at a low level in 2017 to 2.6% in 2018, although it remained at a moderate level. Among the components, the housing rental component increased more rapidly, reflecting the impact of earlier rises in private residential rents (Figure 2). A broader analysis shows that nominal labor costs and commercial property rents grew slightly faster, making local cost pressures more pronounced. As inflation in some major import sources of Hong Kong rose, import price inflation also increased accordingly.

Figure 2: Basic Consumer Price Inflation. Source: Government Statistics Department.

# Labor Market

The labor market remained robust in 2018 (Figure 3). The unemployment rate decreased from 3.1% in 2017 to 2.8% in 2018, the lowest level since 1997. Unemployment rates declined in most major service sectors, with the accommodation and food services sector experiencing the most significant drop. With further increases in total employment and private sector job vacancies, overall labor demand continued to strengthen, and the labor force participation rate also rose slightly. Under tightening labor market conditions, real wages and incomes increased further.

Figure 3: Labor Market Conditions. Source: Government Statistics Department.

# Stock Market

The performance of the Hong Kong stock market saw a sharp reversal in 2018. Driven by strong upward momentum in 2017, the Hang Seng Index reached a historical high of 33,484 points in January 2018 (Figure 4). However, market optimism quickly reversed as major central banks tightened monetary policies, Sino-US trade tensions escalated, and investor concerns arose over slowing local economic growth. The Hang Seng Index fell to a low of 24,586 points in October, closing at 25,846 points by year-end—a 13.6% decline from the previous year. Nevertheless, average daily turnover rose from 882 billion HKD in 2017 to 1,074 billion HKD, while the total fundraising from initial public offerings (IPOs) in Hong Kong also surged due to the listing of several companies in emerging and innovative industries.

Figure 4 Asset Prices  
Data Source: Hong Kong Valuation and Survey Department and Hong Kong Exchanges and Clearing Limited.

# Real Estate Market

The residential property market remained robust in the first half of 2018, but cooled in the second half amid escalating Sino-US trade tensions, global stock market adjustments, and rising prime lending rates. Overall property prices fell 9% from their peak between July and December, although they still recorded a 2% increase for the year (Figure 4). Due to significantly reduced buying and selling activities in both new and second-hand markets in the second half of the year, property transaction volumes in 2018 dropped 7% year-on-year to 57,247 transactions. Moreover, housing affordability remained tight, with price-to-income and income leverage ratios at 17.0 and 75.7 respectively, both far above long-term averages. On the other hand, non-residential property prices rose overall in 2018, though they slightly declined toward the end of the year. For the full year, prices and rents continued to increase, while rental yields remained at low levels.

# Economic Prospects

# Economic environment

Due to slower global economic growth, it is expected that Hong Kong's economic growth will slow down in 2019. In particular, with the external environment full of challenges, Hong Kong's export performance is expected to remain under pressure. Locally, although the low unemployment rate and increased household income will continue to support private consumption, the growth of private consumption is expected to slow down partly due to weakened consumer confidence and the wealth erosion effect from earlier asset price adjustments. In terms of fixed capital formation, although construction and building activities are expected to grow steadily with increased housing supply, businesses may become more cautious about capital investment due to increased uncertainty in the economic environment. The government predicts that the real GDP growth rate for 2019 will be between 2 and 3 percent, while the latest forecasts from private sector analysts average 2.3 percent.

# Inflation and the labor market

Due to the slowdown in global growth, including in Hong Kong, external prices and local cost pressures may be alleviated, and it is therefore expected that inflationary pressure will remain moderate in 2019. The recent fall in newly signed residential rents will also have a restraining effect on inflation. Market consensus forecasts an overall inflation rate of 2.2% in 2019, while the government expects a basic inflation rate of 2.5%. It is expected that with continued economic growth and a thriving tourism industry in Hong Kong, the labor market situation will remain tight. Private sector analysts predict that the unemployment rate will remain at around 3% in 2019.

# Uncertain factors and risks

The economic outlook for 2019 is influenced by uncertainties and risks such as trade tensions, the future direction of U.S. monetary policy, mainland China's economic performance, Brexit, and other geopolitical situations. Additionally, if these uncertainties intensify and persist in the long term, financial market sentiment and business confidence could be significantly affected, exerting downward pressure on local asset markets and real economic activities.

In addition, the residential property market is influenced by numerous external and local factors, and its future remains uncertain. Externally, the uncertainty surrounding US-China trade tensions could affect market sentiment, economic prospects, and financial conditions, clouding the outlook for the Hong Kong property market. Locally, although economic growth has slowed, employment and income growth remain largely stable, which may support demand for residential properties. Hong Kong's interest rates are partly dependent on future changes in US policy rates, though the direction of those rates remains unclear. In the long term, due to increased new housing completions over the past few years, and with the government committed to boosting land and housing supply, the gap between housing supply and demand is expected to narrow.

# Banking system performance

Despite increased external headwinds such as the US-China trade conflict, Brexit, and the normalization of interest rates, which heightened financial market volatility, the banking sector in Hong Kong remained resilient in 2018. The banking sector’s capital and liquidity positions were sound, and asset quality remained good. Rising interest rates widened net interest margins, boosting bank profits significantly.

# Balance sheet trends

The banking system continued steady growth in 2018, with the balance sheet expanding by 5.9%. Facing ongoing economic uncertainties, such as trade conflicts between major economies and interest rate hikes, enterprises became more conservative in obtaining new loans. The annual growth rate of total loans slowed to 4.4%, compared to 16.1% in 2017. This growth was driven by increases in loans used in Hong Kong (+6.5%) and loans used outside Hong Kong (+2%). On the other hand, due to the uncertain global trade environment, trade financing declined by 7.6%. The growth of related loans in mainland China also slowed from 17.5% in 2017 to 1.4% in 2018.

The total amount of debt securities held by the banking system continued to account for 22% of total assets at the end of 2018, the same as in 2017. Since most of these debt securities were investment-grade debt securities issued by governments and banks, the associated credit risk remained at a low level.

From the perspective of depositors, total deposits increased by 5% in 2018, a smaller increase than the 8.7% growth in 2017. Some banks raised time deposit rates in anticipation of continued interest rate hikes in the United States, encouraging depositors to convert their current and savings deposits into time deposits to lock in funds. The proportion of current and savings deposits in total deposits fell from 57.4% in the previous year to 51.4% by the end of 2018, leading to higher funding costs. Since the growth in total deposits outpaced the growth in total loans, the overall loan-to-deposit ratio slightly declined from 73% at the end of 2017 to 72.6% at the end of 2018 (Figure 5).

Figure 5: Loans and Deposits in the Banking System

# Capital Adequacy Level

The banking system has ample capital, indicating it has a strong buffer to withstand potential shocks. The capital ratio is at a historical high since the implementation of Basel III; the composite total capital ratio of locally registered authorized institutions increased from 19.1% at the end of 2017 to 20.3% by the end of 2018 (Figure 6).

Figure 6: Consolidated Capital Ratio of Locally Registered Authorized Institutions

The Basel III leverage ratio became effective on January 1, 2018; this ratio is a non-risk-based regulation designed to limit excessive leverage accumulation in the banking system. By the end of 2018, the leverage ratio was 8.0%, significantly higher than the statutory minimum requirement of 3% (Figure 7).

Figure 7 Comprehensive Leverage Ratio of Locally Registered Accredited Institutions

# Liquidity Status

The liquidity position of the banking system remains robust, reflecting its strong capacity to effectively withstand potential financial and economic pressures. In terms of short-term liquidity (covering one-month funding), the average liquidity coverage ratio for Category 1 institutions was 167.6% in the fourth quarter, far exceeding the 90% statutory minimum requirement applicable in 2018. The average liquidity maintenance ratio for Category 2 institutions was 54.3%, also significantly higher than the 25% statutory minimum requirement (Figure 8).

zh:
# 貨幣穩定

2018年港元利率普遍上升，而港元現貨匯率則回軟，並貼近弱方兌換保證匯率的水平。儘管如此，港元外匯及貨幣市場運作仍然暢順有序。聯繫匯率制度是香港貨幣及金融穩定的基石，並繼續展現其承受強大衝擊的能力。

# 目標

香港貨幣政策的主要目標是維持貨幣穩定，即確保港元匯價穩定，使港元在外匯市場兌美元的匯率保持在7.75至7.85港元兌1美元的區間內。該貨幣體制主要採用貨幣發行局制度，規定由外匯基金所持的美元儲備向貨幣基礎提供最少百分之百的支持；貨幣基礎若有變動，美元儲備亦必須作出相應增減，與貨幣基礎的變動百分之百配合。

貨幣基礎（表1）包括：
- 負債證明書（為3間發鈔銀行發行的銀行紙幣提供十足支持）
- 政府發行的流通紙幣及硬幣
- 銀行在金管局所持結算戶口的結餘總額（即總結餘）
- 金管局代表政府發行的外匯基金票據及債券。

金管局透過自動利率調節機制及履行兌換保證的堅決承諾來維持港元匯率的穩定。若市場對港元的需求大過供應，令市場匯率轉強至7.75港元兌1美元的強方兌換保證匯率，金管局會向銀行沽出港元、買入美元，使總結餘增加及港元利率下跌，從而令港元匯率從強方兌換保證匯率水平回復至7.75到7.85的兌換範圍內。相反，若港元供過於求，令市場匯率轉弱至7.85港元兌1美元的弱方兌換保證匯率，金管局會向銀行買入港元，使總結餘減少及推高港元利率，港元匯率隨之由弱方兌換保證匯率水平回復至兌換範圍內。

# 2018年回顧

# 匯率穩定

在港元與美元負息差擴闊帶動套息活動的背景下，港元匯率自年初以來逐步轉弱。於4月12日，弱方兌換保證在2005年訂於7.85水平以來首度被觸發。全年計，弱方兌換保證在2018年合共被觸發27次，分別在4月被觸發13次，5月6次，以及8月8次。儘管如此，港元交易仍然暢順有序，港元匯率於4月中至9月中在弱方兌換保證匯率7.85附近徘徊（圖1）。其後港元匯率略為轉強，部分反映假期、季結及年結臨近，銀行同業流動性收緊，帶動部分套息交易平倉。同時，某程度上港元亦受到11月初股市氣氛好轉支持。整體而言，港元外匯市場在2018年全年正常運作。

圖1 2018年市場匯率

由於弱方兌換保證被觸發，總結餘與未償還外匯基金票據及債券總額由2017年底的12,268億港元，下降至2018年底的11,362億港元（圖2）。年內，金管局按照聯繫匯率制度（聯匯制度）的設計，應銀行要求於弱方兌換保證匯率7.85的水平，購入合共1,035億港元，總結餘因而由2017年底的1,798億港元下降至2018年底的764億港元。年內未償還外匯基金票據及債券總額沒有明顯變動。貨幣基礎仍然由外匯儲備提供十足支持。

於2018年底，總結餘與未償還外匯基金票據及債券總額為11,362億港元。

圖2 2018年總結餘及未償還外匯基金票據及債券

# 貨幣市場

由於觸發弱方兌換保證後銀行同業流動性減少，以及市場預期美國加息，香港銀行同業拆息在2018年內普遍上升。受新股集資活動相關的資金需求增加及季節性流動資金需求帶動，短期銀行同業拆息更出現較大波幅（圖3）。整體而言，短期銀行同業拆息在2018年大致維持在低於基本利率的水平。鑑於銀行體系資金成本上升，在9月下旬美國聯邦基金利率目標範圍上調後，銀行調高最優惠貸款利率12.5至25基點。

因應年內美國聯邦基金利率目標範圍4次合共上調100基點，由1.25至1.50厘上調至2.25至2.50厘，基本利率於3月22日、6月14日、9月27日及12月20日合共上調100基點，由1.75厘上調至2.75厘。基本利率的調整是按照2009年3月26日宣布的經修訂計算公式作出。按照該公式，基本利率定於美國聯邦基金利率目標範圍下限加50基點的水平，或隔夜與1個月香港銀行同業拆息的5天移動平均數的平均值水平，以兩者中較高者為準。

圖3 2018年香港銀行同業拆息

港元遠期匯率折讓在首4個月擴大，大致跟隨港元與美元息差的走勢，其中12個月港元遠期匯率點子在4月中達到負620點子（圖4）。其後隨着港元與美元的負息差收窄，港元遠期匯率折讓略為縮小，然後在第4季再度擴大。整體而言，香港貨幣市場繼續正常運作。貼現窗借貸由2017年的103億港元增至2018年的402億港元。

圖4 2018年美元兌港元遠期匯率點子

# 聯繫匯率制度

聯匯制度自1983年實施以來，直是維持香港貨幣及金融穩定的重要基石；並在多次區內以至全球金融危機考驗下，展現其承受強大衝擊的能力。由於港元轉弱，作為聯匯制度設計一部分的弱方兌換保證於4月、5月及8月被多次觸發。資金流出港元，是香港利率正常化的必經過程，亦是聯匯制度下的正常運作。為增進各界對有關操作及聯匯制度機制的了解，金管局致力向公眾闡釋聯匯制度的技術細節，並展示香港金融體系應對衝擊的能力。政府亦堅決維持聯匯制度。外匯及貨幣市場保持穩定，進一步鞏固公眾對政府的承擔，以及港元作為支付及保值貨幣的信心。國際貨幣基金組織在與香港進行2018年第四條磋商時，重申對聯匯制度的支持，並指出聯匯制度仍然是最適合香港的貨幣制度，是維持穩定的支柱，有助確保經濟持續增長、維持競爭力及促進龐大的金融服務業暢順運作。

鑑於穩健的銀行體系對聯匯制度的正常運作具關鍵作用，金管局繼續密切監察銀行的信用、流動性及利率風險管理，以及壓力測試結果，並維持對銀行的企業、物業相關及內地相關貸款的監管，以確保銀行體系具備承受衝擊的能力。銀行持有大量外匯基金票據及債券，可經貼現窗用作換取港元流動資金，為利率大幅波動的情況提供有效緩衝。金管局隨時準備透過調整外匯基金票據及債券的發行量以提供額外流動性，以應對資金可能急劇流出港元的情況。金管局亦提醒市民審慎管理市場及利率風險，並為可能出現的市場波動作好準備。

為提高貨幣發行局帳目的透明度，自1998年10月起，外匯基金已有部分資產被指定用作支持貨幣基礎。支持比率（即支持資產相對貨幣基礎的比率）於2018年在107.8至109.9%之間上落，並無觸及上限或下限。該比率於12月31日為109.9%（圖5）。在聯匯制度下，雖然已指定某些外匯基金資產作為支持組合，但外匯基金的全部資產均可用作支持港元匯率。外匯基金的龐大財政資源，能在面對突如其來的衝擊時為保障香港的貨幣及金融穩定提供強力後盾。

圖5 2018年支持比率每日變動

# 貨幣發行委員會

外匯基金諮詢委員會轄下的貨幣發行委員會（貨幣發行委員會）負責監察和探討與香港貨幣及金融穩定有關的課題。在2018年，貨幣發行委員會探討的課題包括多國央行聯合退出非常規貨幣政策對在香港的境外銀行美元貸款供應造成的潛在影響、港元貨幣需求的利率敏感度，以及聯匯制度自3項優化措施以來的運作機制及理論。貨幣發行委員會會議紀錄及金管局向其呈交的貨幣發行局制度運作報告，均載於金管局網站。

# 研究

香港金融研究中心（研究中心）繼續支持貨幣政策、銀行業及金融範疇的研究工作。過去4年，研究中心更着重政策方面的研究，從所舉辦的研討會及訪問學者計劃尤其可見一斑。一方面，研究中心與主要中央銀行及政策研究機構合作，聯合舉辦更多政策相關的研討會。另一方面，在2016年推出專題研究學者計劃，支持更多與金管局政策制定相關的研究項目。

在2018年，研究中心合共邀請16位研究學者到訪，並發表了25份研究論文。年內研究中心亦舉辦了4場國際研討會：
- 於1月舉行的「第9屆中國經濟年度國際研討會」，主題為「中國房地產市場及其對經濟與金融穩定的影響」。研討會由研究中心、國務院發展研究中心市場經濟研究所及中國人民銀行金融研究所合辦，集中討論內地房地產市場相關的課題及風險。
- 於10月舉行由金管局及國際結算銀行合辦的「匯率與貨幣政策框架」研討會。研討會為國際結算銀行於香港的亞太區辦事處成立20周年的慶祝活動之一，旨在探討匯率在貨幣政策框架中的角色。
- 於11月舉行的「2018年中央銀行金融市場微結構的年度研討會」。研討會討論金融市場微結構理論研究、實證研究結果及近期發展相關的政策影響。
- 於11月舉行由金管局、歐洲中央銀行及美國聯邦儲備委員會合辦的「中國經濟的新時代」中國專家網絡研討會。研討會討論內地經濟正面對的迫切問題及其對全球經濟的影響，並特別着重與中央銀行決策者相關的政策議題。這是中國專家網絡研討會首次在歐洲以外地區舉行。
